Philosophy is an attempt to understand the world around us and the reasons for it and us and the things that we do. A lot of it can be introspective and deals with questions as to the ideal society and the motivations of people and why they do things. Whilst I like philosophy there exists a caveat within it for me as a central issue:
Namely, Philosophy can encourage apathy as regards too much thinking and not doing, or not putting ones thoughts into a physical manifestation in the real world, this is of course where philosophy can encounter the realms of politics, economics and sociology. But I find for my own introspective analysis that philosophers as a whole tend to to be sterotypically disconnected with real world issues and more focused on spouting platitudes and stoking their own egos. An idea is nothing if not acted upon, Plato took no action to create his republic of ideal guardians, Machiavelli espoused his theories but did not connive and manipulate to put them into effect, Locke took his notions of a liberal or liberated society of freedom but did he campaign for it, did he issue speeches or create a movement or cause to do so? One may of course retort that he practised it by allowing others to do as they do, to which I say the ideal or idea not put into affect is nothing, and less than nothing it detracts. I may have the idea of making a sandwich to appease my hunger, but without the inclination or will to do so i shall remain hungry.
Buddha drew an interesting parallel here when he described a person shot by a poisoned arrow, he states that the man could enquire from whence direction the arrow came, where it was made, what it was made from, who shot the arrow, what is the poison etc etc, but only by dealing with the arrow, i.e. by acting upon it can he affect his life. Thus whilst I admire philosophy and love it myself, I find that most take no action from it, worse they may become armchair philsophers, worse still they may stoke their own egos and platitudes and lastly they may, surrounded only by followers lose touch of the real world they once tried to understand. Wisdom can therefore be a snare, for it is not a conclusion that is important, indeed only dead fish swim with the stream but the evermore exploration and continuance of the journey, once one reaches a definite conclusion and no longer takes an action, is it not that he/she is indistinguishable from the corpses of those laid to rest in previous generations? he/she that states that they now know truth are thus now nobody, for they have stopped action, thus it is that to know, or truly know is to know that you know nothing and thus one lives by continuing on the journey of trying to understand. Philsophy is therefore a journey, for which the action of walking that path IS the aim, the quaint phrase: It is not the destination but the journey that matters springs to mind.

Notes on Crashcourse Philosophy Video 1: What is Philosophy?

* In this series we will examine questions that can’t necessarily be answered by the sciences
* We will evaluate the world rather than taking it as a given
* Philosophy began in Ancient Greece, at the time that Buddhism and Jainism were being developed in Asia
* Distinction between philos and mythos, science and storytelling, taking shape
* Bards used stories, and earlier philosophers used analytic methods which were more scientific
* Philosophy means love of wisdom
* Philosophy originally meant the academic study of anything, such as astronomy and mathematics, etc
* Later, a distinction formed between empirical studies (sciences) and philosophy, which focused on questions
* Philosophers are constantly thinking about questions, even if they can never find out the answers for sure
* Philosophy is broken up into Metaphysics has to do with questions about the nature of reality
* Ex: What kind of being am I
* Epistemology studies the nature and scope of knowledge
* Ex: Can I ever be certain about anything?
* Value theory: made up of ethics and aesthetics
* Ethics: the study of how we should live with each other
* How should I live? How should I treat myself, animals, strangers, etc?
* Aesthetics, the other branch of value theory, has to do with beauty and art. What is beauty and does it even exist?
* Logic is the philosopher’s toolbox, which provides a clear and systematic way to get at answers. Philosophers avoid fallacies and use reasoning to investigate the questions posed by metaphysics, epistemology, and value theory.
* Contrary to popular belief, philosophy is relevant to nearly everything we do
* We will first try to understand each view of the world before critically thinking about it/challenging it
* Success in philosophy means knowing how to think






Questions: 

What does philosophy mean? When did it first arise, and where? What’s the difference between philos and mythos? What did philosophy originally study, and how has the field narrowed over the years? What are the three main branches in philosophy today? Give an example of a question that each branch investigates. What is the philosopher’s toolbox, and the goal of philosophy?

I love philosophy, but I'm not going to lie. Challanging my own beliefs is often frightening.

But I believe I should challange them, because if I discover an alternate set of values that I agree upon more than the old, then that's okay.

Because I believe in most cases, "accuracy" to myself now is better than consistency for those around me.

But, being inconsistent scares me because I think it implies a sort of instability.

And I think instability is generally frowned upon in human societies. Because perhaps one assumes small change will inevitably lead to large changes, and large changes may threaten one's life.

Perhaps most people have an inherit fear of change; particularly as they grow older, as they're subconsiously aware of the fragility of their life; and people subconsiously associate exterior changes to internal changes.
An inbalance in homeostasis. Because that imbalance usually means harm. Threat.

Three Major Branch of Philosophy
Metaphysics - studies of nature of reality
Epistemology - studies of nature of knowledge
Value Theory - nature of Ethics & Aesthetics

The Foundation of Philosophy
Logic - the way of building strong Arguments that don't fall to Fallacy.

Great video. The word philos seems unlikely to stand opposite of mythos though. Logos is the word you're looking for. Your etymology of the word philosophy points out that 'philos' has to do with 'love' in ancient greek. You see it in pedofile too, paidion (=kids)+ file(=love,same stem as philos) lover of children or Philantropy, philos (love) + antropos (men/humans) love for humanity. Logos, which means 'word' or 'science' in ancient greek you'll find in words Psychology, psychy (soul) + logos(study) or cardiology, cardio (=heart) + logos (study). In all honesty, this video should be renamed: "What is Western Philosophy?" It is really sad to see educational videos such as this one plagued with eurocentrism. It is assumed that ancient philosophy automatically translates to ancient Greek philosophy. What about Indian philosophy? or Middle Eastern philosophy? or Chinese philosophy? or African philosophy? or Native American philosophy?  Moreover, the art of philosophy does not "date back to ancient Greece." Ancient Egyptian philosophy dates back to around 2,400 BC. Way before even pre-Socratic writers. The Vedic period in India dates back to about 1,700 BC. 

Other than that, it was an enjoyable and concise video.

there is a definition of philosophy i read somewhere which takes philosophy to be the academic study of anything, which is mentioned in this episode as the definition the ancient greek philosophers used, but adds an exclusion of practices that are already well established. this way the empirical sciences, mathematics, arts,, are excluded (with exceptions (e.g. new areas of empirical science, theories, styles of art,, while they are still not ready for any serious publicity even within it's respective practise)), and so are the applications of extant philosophics (i use philosophics := philosophic things, much like mathematics := mathematic things (not to be confused with the study of mathematics, often abbreviated as Mathematics, and not always using a majuscule M to disambiguate the study from the thing studied)) (where one does not create new philosophics, but applies existing philosophics to something), though applied philosophy includes some creation of new philosophics, and those acts of philosophy that do create philosophics would be considered part of philosophy, while those that do not, wouldn't. some consider the intention to create philosophics to be philosophic, while others would argue that we cannot easily know the intentions of other people, so the result is what matters, i agree with the former, while acknowledging that we can only assert judgements about what we know (which includes conditional judgements (which some say is the totality of mathematics, though i disagree with them on this, though this is about philosophy, not mathematics, so i won't digress here into my perspective on the nature of mathematics)) have your pick i guess, but in the spirit of consciousness, be prepared to understand why you chose what you did.
by the definition of philosophy that given above, most of what might be called philosophy would not be philosophy, but would have, instead, it's own designation. however, all philosophers really do when they do philosophy, regardless of which(non)established practice they study in, would be philosophy, because it is always just outside of the (or not in an) established practice. all that is usually referred to as philosophy was at some point, by the definition given above, part of philosophy, and the only reason it is not any more is that it has matured into an established body of knowledge with it's own culture: practises, form, history, and myth.

Yet, "Why do you do what you do, why do you think what you think, and why do you feel what you feel?" ( 0:31 ) 100 to 1 odds the video will not answer them - it will only delve into history (and it did) - that is, present obsolete (since I am here now) thinking. Note that many philosophers also like to hide in history in order to avoid addressing ongoing issues themselves, as well as engage in fruitless lexicon games (where a simple agreement on definitions is needed), or immerse themselves in applied (lower) philosophies (such as the video's 'golf') (or business or economics or politics, to present a few more serious examples), spinning their wheels in a subjective haze...

Interesting that the video brings up 'science', but it is wrong in saying that science is not the venue for answering such questions - it is - in a deconstructive sense - although it does need guidance (which it gets from philosophy) (which in turn is affected by verified knowledge) (which is obtained through science). You could say that science has the fuel to continue ("I want to save the world!" "I want to discover new things!" "I want to improve life!"), but it does not have a guidance system (hence it is still easily commandeered by evil). There is one question that science will never address (although it does have input): the Greatest of the Great Questions of Life: "Why Bother?" (for, you must admit, you need to answer that even before you turn to any of the other Great Questions of Life, because... why bother?).

1:18 does describe the difference between science (describe) and philosophy (evaluate), but 1:21 right after that returns to muddleness. "Taking nothing as a given" is the venue of science, and "setting assumptions aside" displays a misunderstanding of what we need to think and progress (assumptions, generalizations, and classifications are necessary tools for perceiving and judging - necessary for decision making, our only task is to refine them).

The video asks, "What is philosophy?" ( 2:03 ) and my guess is it will delve into the history of philosophy (what philosophy 'was') (it 'was' science - but the wrong approach - trying to divine reality by sitting around thinking), which is no longer what philosophy 'is'. The answer to what philosophy is right now is it is a political, academically self-serving, muddled subjective mess - in fact Stephen Hawking noted that "Philosophy is Dead" (meaning it currently contributes nothing of import to the world). Well, it isn't 'dead' - I found it - in the toilet. (thanks, 20th Century).

And the video will probably miss the point as to what philosophy actually gives us, and it will not recognize that EVERYONE already has a philosophy - the problem is that they are horrible hodge-podges of trite platitudes that only masquerade as philosophy (all this according to me, by the way). Everyone has one because they would not be able to make any decisions (higher than animal) without one - it is what you weigh such decisions (and you resultant actions) against.

The video immediately gets off on the wrong foot ( 2:05 ) noting that philosophy is an opinion you may have toward a certain topic (the example given being 'golf'). That is not 'philosophy' proper, that is 'applied philosophy', which is classified as a lower sub-form (by me) - meaning you cannot guide your lives by them - they are not overall life-guiding philosophies (such as my philosophy of broader survival for the space age) - they are, in fact (according to me) ongoing symptoms of universal human cluelessness (trying to get through life without an adequate life-guiding philosophy (and there are none yet) (and religions have failed) (enter me).

Curiously (noting what I've given you above), the video says it will address philosophy even more narrowly than the philosophy of golf (meaning the video's writer doesn't have a clue).

"Philos and Mythos" ( 2:34 ) - nice. Give some credit to the ancient Greeks - noble attempts at elevating the defective mindsets of their time (much like I am doing).

Saying that "science is about answers, and philosophy is about questions" is misleading - science begins with questions (although not the BIG questions, and certainly not the biggest of all: "Why Bother?") (which the video will surely miss, since it is my discovery, and the word is not out there yet).

The video then attempts to give a few of the BIG questions, erroneously beginning with "What is the world like?" (which has been passed on to science). Ditto for "What is the nature of reality?" So the video is still stuck in the ancient past - that is, merely speculating about reality, and not really going out and testing it. Today, philosophy is where we get our values (including the Ultimate Value of Life - which I've discovered and have given you in my philosophy, thank you very much, now go read it).

Metaphysics ( 4:27 ) needs a new definition, and I will supply it: "Metaphysics is that branch of faulty thinking where people erroneously believe their speculations to be true (for whatever reason - and it could be knavish)."

Epistimology ( 4:46 ) "Is what we know true?" also needs an answer, and I will supply that, too: "The only useful knowledge is Verified Knowledge, and 'verified' can be to different degrees, meaning our knowledge becomes a mere model of reality - good for forming assumptions, generalizations, and classifications. So the question becomes, "What is the degree of knowledge, or perspective gained (or mental/mathematical model of reality) good enough for?" If it is good enough for engineering (such as building a reliable bridge), then it is good enough for engineering, but perhaps it is still not good enough for securing higher consciousness in a harsh and deadly universe... As for those philosophers who deny reality, my response to them is, "Reality is that which will annihilate you, whether you acknowledge it or not."

The video then addresses Value Theory ( 5:38 ), dividing it into Ethics, or "Good vs. Evil", and "Beauty". Beauty (aesthetics) does not belong with ethics, however (according to me), it is a lower psychological issue (science) (both of which are currently messed up due to cluelessness).

Sad that the video's writer did not realize that any 'value' automatically comes with an associated 'goal' (to secure that value), which is what actually determines good and evil (they are goal-driven), and, ultimately, what is 'beautiful' (and why), and it answers "How should I live?" ( 6:08 ), as well as answering 6:16 (what obligations should you have toward other people, animals, and the earth). Just to note, on 'beauty', it has been found that the 'most beautiful' is merely the 'most average' (as a recent study on human faces indicated) (but this may only hold in a clueless world - for I have found that true beauty is held in dynamics (action), and not in statics (posing) (and it is why humans are still posers - they don't know any better).

6:22 demonstrates continued universal human cluelessness, but 6:27 is on the right track (good and evil are determined by values), but it is still hazy (clueless) - because it is not by values directly, but the associate goal (and the video's use of "value's" in the plural also illustrates ongoing universal human cluelessness - otherwise it would have recognized the existence of an Ultimate Value for Life (which would give us an associated Ultimate Goal, which would give us the 'ultimate' determination toward good and evil - an ability that humans, being clueless, still do not possess)...

Logic ( 7:07 ) is an interesting aspect of philosophy - both inductive and deductive reasoning (just to mention those - since the video did not - maybe they cover it in their next video on philosophy). The video does make a finer error - 'logic' is not the tools in the toolbox, it creates the tools (which are assumptions, generalizations, and classifications, which give us 'perspective' - which is the real tool - and the more perspectives we have in our toolbox, the better equipped we will be when peering into the unknown).

At 7:46 the video is right in saying "you have already done philosophy", but it is off the mark in explaining it - it is not "your thinking about the world and your place in it", nor is it figuring out what you value - it is your weighing your decisions (higher than those of an animal) against your Ultimate Value in Life (which, sorry to say, is not what it should be) (your still being clueless).

8:05 is a healthy approach (try to understand a philosophical view, and then test its worth) (and your own understanding, just to be fair). Sadly, most people tend to blindly dismiss any new thinking (such as mine), choosing instead to cling to their inherited deficient mental baggage, usually for social reasons.

The first thing my philosophy teacher teached us in school was: Learning to PHILOSOPHISE is useful because it means to learn HOW TO REALLY THINK, with an open mind, with a critical mind. She used a method of teaching in which we had to reflext about a certain topic, proposing our own answers, then we would try to discuss between ourselves and make arguments to support our positions, and only after that she would explain us the ideas and theories of the renown philosophers in the matter. Sometimes we had to read extracts of philosophy texts and she would explain us who to read and about the language (because most of philosophers write in an overly complex way), sometimes we would have to write a two pages essay about a modern topic like an ethic dilema, sometimes we would interprete the behaviour of people in a movie... She was great teacher. Philosophy is awesome.

I feel impulsed to help explain the flaws in determinism ( the belief that all actions and thoughts are made purely through past experiences and/or chemical makeup and other such physical factors such as hormones). The simple flaw is "If all thoughts and actions are pre-determined and not made by the person, how can you claim to KNOW anything?" The thing is, if there is no free will, there is no free thought, and that means that you can not claim that you KNOW what you are saying is true. Beyond that, if you believe that only the physical universe exists then how do you explain the existence of knowledge itself, or any other non-physical things such as truth, love, reason, and faith? We know through science that knowledge, truth, and other such concepts are non-physical through, so if u claim only the physical universe exists then u can not by nature have truth, knowledge or reason. And once again if these things are physical (simply neurons and chemicals ect) then there is no objective standard meaning no TRUTH. To put this in simple terms, you can not believe to know anything unless you claim the existence of free will, and a non-physical world. Please like this comment if u wish to spur debate, or like this reasoning, and feel free to comment. I hope to receive some truly insightful replies.

You show a nice differentiation of the various disciplines in philosophy. I like to use similar one inspired by Kants essay on what philosophy is.
Still, if I look at some classical philosophers, I often see that these differentiations don't point to actual differences. For eample, in Platos Politaia, you'll see various aestetic arguments which are used to make a point about Ethics. Since Plato connected the good with truth, it also became an epestimological argument.
Personally, I prefer theories which start with Epistomology and use this as a basis for other fields. For example, the question "what should I do" seems less poductiv than "how could I be deceived in what's the right thing to do?" After all, you can easily imagine two characters who follow the same ethical principle and who fiercely oppose each other.

Probably been pointed out, but you mixed up so much when explaining the origin of the word philosophy. First, probably worst of all you said φίλος (philos) instead of φύσις (physis). φίλος (philos) does not have a meaning anywhere near close to science. It actually means friend. φύσις (physis) is the word you're looking for, and could roughly, in a garbled way, mean "science" but its much more accurate to describe it with the word "nature."

Second μύθος (muthos) isn't the word you're looking for. μύθος (muthos) is contrasted with the term λόγος (logos). The first meaning a fictional kind of story (roughly) and the latter meaning a (historical) account of events or even reason itself. The word you're looking to contrast φύσις (physis) with is νόμος (nomos) which roughly translates to laws or social custom.

Philosophy is essentially, especially for the Greeks, about separating φύσις (physis) from the νόμος (nomos). That is to say its about separating the nature of things from the social customs and practices that we take for granted.

SOPHIA (wisdom) is an old term that is used sometimes even in myths. PHILOSOPHIA itself does not even become general parlance among those who inquire until after Socrates. Hey peeps at Crash Course, as a Philosophy graduate and post-graduate student, I am really pleased you are starting this series. It looks like its gonna be a lot of fun.

Also as a would-be professional philosopher (if that's even a thing) I have some suggestions and questions about the course.
I want to bring to your attention the (seemingly but not actually) new field of study: African Philosophy. I was hoping that you might include the major thinkers of both ancient and contemporary African countries, as well as those from the African Diaspora. 


I also want to challenge your phrasing of the origins of philosophy being in ancient Greece.
As much as we return to the brilliant thinkers of that era, the phrasing seems to imply that there is one center, one origin, for the vast body of scholarship we term philosophy. In our western traditions we often forget that philosophy is fundamental to all humans from all contexts, and fail to recognize the work from non-western contexts and traditions, which has the double effect of closing ourselves off to brilliant inquiry and valuable thinking, as well as perpetuating modes of thought that enable prejudicial thinking, and thus contribute to anti-African and anti-POC discourse. It may interest you to know that some of our first systems of formal logic originate from Africa, not to mention other subjects. I will of course provide names of authors for your perusal.

I also want to challenge what seems like a privileging of analyticity. As much as we love being logical-positivists, I would encourage you to explore the problems with the ideas of reason and rationality, particularly with notions of the a priori. And I do hope you sneak in some continental thinking.

Lastly, I want to know if you peeps will be touching on any philosophy of language- a slippery field which nonetheless has major consequences for all areas of philosophical inquiry.

Sorry for long post :)

First of all, ditch the metaphysics start using word ontology. Why? Well, because ontology covers a bit more than metaphysics does. It covers physics too.
Epistemology doesn't really ask questions like "am I real?". It's about "What can I know?". "Am I real" is part of ontology.
Finally.

in the last panel of the intro, it says that while a cat is in a box and can't be observed, it is both dead AND alive at the same time. that's not philosophy; it's quantum physics. schrodinger's cat is a thought experiment in which a cat is placed in a box with a device that releases cyanide if a radioactive atom decays, which is a 50/50 chance of happening. the ATOM cannot be determined to have decayed or not while it's not observed, and THUS it can't be determined whether the device released the cyanide, killing the cat, or if it didn't, and the cat is alive and well. schrodinger's thought experiment was meant to push the logic of quantum physics to its limits, which unfortunately caused lots of misconceptions and confusion regarding the topic of quantum superposition, as well as the thought experiment itself.

As Mortimer Adler once wrote "Philosophy means understanding reality in the light of eternity".  That is, the philosopher tries to uncover the ultimate truths of reality.  Why?  I think it has something to do with sleeping more soundly at night.  One of my philosophy professors once told us that, ultimately, all philosophers are directed toward answering the ultimate philosophical question: Why does anything exist at all?  I think the answer is rather obvious.  The cosmos exists because it must; that is, it is impossible for nothing to exist and, since something must exist, that something is the cosmos.  Why can't nothing exist?  The answer to that is a bit more complicated.  If nothing existed, then there would be not energy or matter.  But, without energy and matter, one can not have time and space.  Without time and space, nothing becomes nonexistent.  Of course, the next question that needs to be answered is why does our cosmos have the form it has.  Again, the answer is because it must have that and no other form.  Why?  That one I can not answer at present, but, eventually, some physicist will pop up somewhere and proclaim that the entire structure of the cosmos from the quark up through the Big Bang universe is due to only three equations, each one of which is derivable from the other two.  Like the three legs of a stool that is stable.  A sort of Scientific Trinity.  Hope he pops up soon because quantum, relativity, and string theory are starting to give everyone a headache.  We need a simpler description of physical reality.

This is what I've feared for too long, philosophy is going to be relegated and degraded by this show to mean some baseless claim which is "philosophical". And if that's an absurd statement viewed by someone outside of my reasoning then I have to ask you this, how much do you know about epistemology or metaphysics? Fundamentally these are two of the largest and most complicated disciplines of philosophy, and yet they were brushed past with the pseudo-intellectual jargon that the layman sees in other media. Value theory (actually called axiology) is a relatively smaller discipline, and one of much less rigor, with people generally settling in one camp and sparsely moving beyond that. If this series accomplishes anything more than creating another buzz feed of philosophy then I will be impressed, but I hold no hope, and the subject I love will probably be further misrepresented to be subjective assertions "argued" to be rational.

If its all about questions then I guess I should propose a question but I try to simplify and relate to common terminology. If Our brains are like an Organic Super Computer, and our brain structure matches that of how the universe seems to form, Could it not then be that the universe is the original Organic super computer with processing power 10^googol compared to anything we have ever seen? Could it be that our universe is a sort of super conscious life form, and as it grows and ages, we slowly evolve?

Could it not be that humans are just one little Bactria within the body of it? If you look at humans as this you begin to pick up parallels on how we affect the world around us and how we seem to do damage, you begin to realize that we may be hostile to our own host. But then again not all Bactria in your body is bad so could it not be that unless we change our ways we will either surpass our planet destroying it and moving on to new places and causing illness or we could run ourselves into the ground.

That is if we do not change our ways and respect not only our planet but the universe as a whole. We do not know the overall impact of what we have done to the universe as a whole or if we have done any damage at all. But it is sure that we have begun to spread. This whole philosophy makes me rethink black holes and how much (at least to me) their ideology mimics that of a virus. Sucking up and absorbing all the that is in its path. A sort of self sustaining assimilator?

Now people are going to write this off as hocus pocus, which is fare as was how I first interpreted that idea, this is due to its striking similarity to the idea of religious thoughts such as Buddhism. I understand that thought because Religion in general has been known to write off science with such bigotry and fear. But this idea allows for a sort of amalgamation of those two ideologies because this could suggest that the universe did not form on its own but was sparked into action but it would also allow for the idea of evolution, which is something that is indisputable.

It would affect how we see ourselves, how we see the grand scare of the universe and how that may just be another layer to the cake of life. It could allow us to explore and reexamine the idea of the Multiverse, Which could relate to the idea of a Super Consciousness and the ideas of Individuality and how it is real but can sometimes be minutiae.

Does that mean that anything is real or is it just information being processed by our brains? Or is everything real and it happened because someone set caused a massive Rube Goldberg like domino effect? Now take this as nothing more then an idea, nothing is solid and nothing is sacred, Information is fluid like time. But like many ideas before it, it defies all our wildest imaginations.

 Its strange nature and obscure ideas based upon theories that are plausible is what compelled me to listen to it fully through. I am one to believed that anything can be true, as long as there is some sort of logical basis behind it. The last thing I have to say is that i know it is strange and that there will be some holes in my theory but then again there are holes in a whole lot of other theories too so I suggest the idea that it isn't as far fetched as one might believe.

+CrashCourse Actually value theory is only one corner of Ethics. In ethics, it is the idea that what determines the difference between right and wrong is some set, or list, of values. You are right when you hold true to that set of values, and wrong when you break with that set of values

But there is so much more to ethics than just different values theories! There are also the relativisms. Relativism in Ethics is the idea that right and wrong is always determined relative to something. Cultural relativism states that morality is relative to what your culture thinks is right. Institutional relativism(whether that institution is a religion or another organization such as the military) states that morality is determined relative to some institution. And personal relativism basically just says that everyone makes their own morality.

From there we get into Utilitarianism, which states that the right thing is whatever does the most good for the most people. And Kant ethics(developed by 18th century philosopher Immanuel Kant), which is a bit complicated to spell out in a youtube comment.

Finally there is another branch of Ethics just getting it's start(which may lead to Ethics becoming a branch of Science) which focuses less on "How should we treat other people" and more on "How do we, as humans, determine how we should treat other people". In other words, it is shifting it's focus from developing "prescriptive" theories to developing "descriptive" theories.

I was psyched about this course but then I feel it's somewhat inaccurate on a number of counts.

I think it's important to have included the whole deal about pre-socratics calling themselves sophists, and philosophers beginning from Socrates, calling themselves philosophers to distinguish themselves between them. (philosopher didn't stem from the word philosophia, but from the greek words phileo sophia, or lovers of wisdom.)

and the key difference between sophists and philosophers was something so groundbreaking - it's why nobody before and nobody after socrates has been quite so important - the socratic elenchos, and its stringent requirements on logic and knowledge. Basically the idea that true premises entailing a conclusion is sound logic.

In my opinion, no course about philosophy can truly escape tackling these ideas, because they are so fundamental, so indispensible to the study of philosophy itself.

Yeah sure, metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and religious philosophy are all branches of philosophy and at some point you need to distinguish them and how the study of philosophy relates to all these items, but I think what's crucially missing is logic, and fundamentally all these other fields still bow down to logic, and how all we strive to separate doxa or mere opinions from actual truth.

It disappoints me that Crash Course is continuing the racist tradition of deciding that philosophy began in Greece. Prior to philosophers and historians of philosophy like Kant and Hegel (and a few others) history of philosophy texts would essentially all start philosophy in places other than Greece. It was only with the rice of scientific racism in the enlightenment that this particular movement of "philosophy begins in Greece" began, and was used largely as a way of denigrating other races (and confirming the superiority of Europeans).

The book "Africa, Asia, and the History of Philosophy" by Peter K. J. Park is an approachable and short read which details this approach to the history of philosophy.

I'm primarily disappointed (though not surprised because this is "the canon" of philosophy as it exists in western society) because Crash Course, and Hank and John (and all the other folk) are generally really good at dissecting this stuff and bringing it up.

Hate to be that guy fact-checking but, as far as I'm aware from 3 years studying philosophy, my books on ancient philosophy beside me, my Ancient Greek primer and the power of online dictionary, philos is not a word in Ancient Greek. Philo was a somewhat important but largely ignored figure in the merger of Greek and Jewish philosphy and theology which contributed greatly to the emerging Christianty of his time.

Philla is a Greek word meaning a form of love like friendly love. A dispassionate love that exists between loyal friends or family. Affectionate regard. Philosophy means something like 'lovers of wisdom' or 'friends of wisdom' or 'dispassionate lovers of wisdom'. Actually just found a mention of philos in Aristotle but only as a non-standard way of writing philia to emphasise a more general concept of philia.

Actual Ancient Greek philsophy was focused on physis (nature) initially, especially the question of ousia (substance). It went on to explore the seemingly sharp division between physis (nature, the natural world, uncivilised man) and nomos (customs, laws, the ordered world of civilised man) and here we find the first true works of ethics. Plato and Aristotle considered these two questions in tandem exploring what it is to be a good man and live a good life by exploring the substance of reality and human beings. As they held radically different views on substance, they came to radically different views with ethics. It also marked the start of the divide between rationalism and empiricism.

As someone who make the ludicrous decision to earn a BA in Philosophy, I always thought of the third branch of philosophy as "Axiology" or "The study of values," which encompasses ethics, aesthetics, AND logic because logic is nothing more than a series of values. True and false, or 1 and 0, are truth values, and the various logical operations simply connect truth values together and form relationships between disparate concepts. Sure, this is purely a semantic critique, but then again, this is philosophy. Bickering about the importance of semantics is what we do.
I argue that Religion and Politics are both subsets of philosophy, and therefore they can never truly be separated.

Not to be a party pooper, but I believe you have the wrong word at 2:36. φίλος doesn't mean "science"; it comes from the word for "love," "affection" or "friendship" (it's the "love" part of φιλοσοφία, "love of wisdom," not the "wisdom" part). The word you want, as a contrast to μύθος, is λόγος (logos), "rationality" or "reason," which is where "logic" and all of our words that end in "-ology" come from - or at least, those are the two words that are normally used in scholarship to describe the contrast you're talking about.

I was a philosophy major.. it was a great experience.. there were a few drawbacks though.. there was essentially no emphasis on eastern philosophy.. everything was western philosophy or a variation of it.. i hope that in this crash course series.. attention would be given to eastern thought as well.. also.. well.. let's begin:

Can one do a crash course in philosophy? a crash course in the ordinary sense of the term suggests a series of lectures that only provide a brief outlines of the subject.. but philosophy is not about the outlines in brevity such as a rough sketch one draws on a napkin of a building.. it is more than that.. it is about becoming the conceptual engineer who will put forth a building constructed from ideas.. from first principles.. philosophy requires time and patience.. it requires not only thinking.. not only challenging one's own ideas.. but having one's most cherished beliefs being challenged.. it's cute and wonderful to have someone provide facts about science or history.. but in philosophy.. as you had pointed out.. the emphasis is not on the facts but on how one thinks.. Radical Idea: instead of assuming the role of a teacher.. assume the role of a student of philosophy yourself.. and find experts in their fields who would be happy to discuss deep ideas.. to question your own beliefs.. and then we will see within that series.. how truly difficult it is for anyone to be aware of all the cognitive biases and moral failings that make us who we are.. such books as Ishmael by Daniel Quinn come to mind.. in fact.. suggested readings should accompany each video in this series.. without a fresh flow of new thought from writers with great ideas.. viewers are likely to remain stagnant in their own modes of thinking.. a kind of static friction.. an inertia that prevents any real growth in the intellect.. and further.. suggested questions should accompany the video as well.. questions that make viewers think well beyond having viewed it for the first time: If chickens had a language and were able to communicate with one another, would I be more or less likely to eat one? Or.. to remain relevant to this video: If beauty is objective and things can be said to have such beauty, then what fundamental principles make a sunset have beauty? Does a toilet have beauty only when it performs its function? Necessarily or conditionally? And if necessarily, does that imply that humans have limits as to what we can appreciate as beautiful? Is it for us to appreciate beauty or to simply accept the inevitable beauty that is life?

I've been thinking about a logical way to explain continuation of experience. First we have to agree that 'I', as in everyone's self, are experiencing the world and are not just a p-zombie. No one can know if anyone but themselves are experiencing this, but we have to agree that everyone else is because it's only logical.

My first thought experiment is this: Assume you can cut someone's brain in half and clone each half. Then put an original halve and a clone halve together twice, making two new brains identical to the first. This is different from a normal cloning thought experiment because it physically clones the existence of the experiencer, not just the information that makes up the brain of the experiencer. This let's me conclude a few things since the universe would allow this to happen:
1. Your continuation of self can run in parallel. This means you somehow experience both brains at the same time.
2. There must be some physical reason you can experienced both brains at once.

Now, I have no conclusion to what this means, but I do have a speculation that fits perfectly. The universe itself somehow is the experiencer, considering that all matter and energy was of the same at one point in time, and more and more complex energy exchanges in general let it 'experience' things. And this is what the sensation of 'consciousness' is. It's out there, and I do not believe it, but it is an idea that ties up all loose strings for what consciousness is. This would in effect means that even worms are technically conscious, but only in the sense that both worms are us would 'see' through the senses and thoughts of a worm. This would also mean everyone is in effect the 'same' experiencer as well. All world lines lead to the big bang as well, and since continuation of existence is defined in four dimensions, then logically everything was at one point interacting in the same system.

I haven't been able to think of another explanation for consciousness that fits everything as well as this one. Better ideas are appreciated. Also, I know I didn't explain myself very well, I've never been able to explain my thoughts properly.
